projectId.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

contract_address.description: The NFT smart contract address to check. This is the address of the NFT contract on the blockchain. If you do not specify a contract_address, we will use the contract associated with your project ID.

token_id.description: NFT token ID to check. This is the token id of the specific NFT token within the contract and it is optional; if absent, any token in the contract will authorize the wallet.

wallet_address.description: Wallet address of the user to authorize the token to if you don't pass in a user name.

email.description: Optional Mintable wallet or Mintable's user email for authorize the NFT to that wallet.

authorized.description: Whether the wallet address has the NFT and is authorized (the wallet address contains the specified NFT or any NFT from the collection)

next_token.description: If next_token exists, it indicates that all the requested results don't fit in a single page, next_token is provided in the response and you can include it in a subsequent request to fetch the next page of results.

wallet_address.description: The wallet address of a user to return the information from this wallet.

email.description: Optional Mintable wallet or Mintable's user email for authorize the NFT to that wallet.

contract_address.description: The NFT smart contract address to check. This is the address of the NFT contract on the blockchain. Optional: If you do not specify a contract_address, we will use the contract associated with your project ID.

token_ids.description: A list of owned NFT token IDs

last_evaluated_key.description: If last_evaluated_key exists, it indicates that all the requested results don't fit in a single page, last_evaluated_key is provided in the response and you can include it in a subsequent request to fetch the next page of results.

used_quantity.description: The quantity of NFTs that have been minted for this project.

contract_address.description: The NFT smart contract address associated with your project ID.

image.description: This is the URL to the image of the item. Can be just about any type of image (including SVG, which will be converted into PNG), and can be IPFS URLs or paths. We recommend using a 350 x 350 image.

animation_url.description:
A URL to a multimedia attachment for the item.The file extensions GLTF, GLB, WEBM, MP4, M4V, OGV, and OGG are supported, along with the audio-only extensions MP3, WAV, and OGA.

Animation_url also supports HTML pages, allowing you to build rich experiences and interactive NFTs using JavaScript canvas WebGL, and more. Scripts and relative paths within the HTML page are now supported. However, access to browser extensions is not supported.

description.description: A human-readable description of the item. Markdown is supported.

attributes.description: These are the attributes for the item, which will show up on the item page on Mintable and other marketplaces.

title.description: Title of this NFT, can be same as name, this is used to list item for sales.

subtitle.description: Short description or subtitle of NFT, can be same as description, this is used to list item for sales.

metadata.description: Required: The new metadata (will replace the existing metadata)

username.description: Optional username that will be tied to this private key/wallet

email.description: Email address that will be tied to this private key/wallet

force_overwrite_linked_wallet.description: Overwrite the currently linked wallet address forcefully

wallet_address.description: The wallet address of a user to return the information from this wallet.

image.description: This is the URL to the image of the item. Can be just about any type of image (including SVG, which will be converted into PNG), and can be IPFS URLs or paths. We recommend using a 350 x 350 image.

animation_url.description:
A URL to a multimedia attachment for the item.The file extensions GLTF, GLB, WEBM, MP4, M4V, OGV, and OGG are supported, along with the audio-only extensions MP3, WAV, and OGA.

Animation_url also supports HTML pages, allowing you to build rich experiences and interactive NFTs using JavaScript canvas WebGL, and more. Scripts and relative paths within the HTML page are now supported. However, access to browser extensions is not supported.

description.description: A human-readable description of the item. Markdown is supported.

attributes.description: These are the attributes for the item, which will show up on the item page on Mintable and other marketplaces.

title.description: Title of this NFT, can be same as name, this is used to list item for sales.

subtitle.description: Short description or subtitle of NFT, can be same as description, this is used to list item for sales.

metadata.description: Metadata for the NFT being minted. If absent, the metadata defined in the project will be used.

token_id.description: A unique token id for the NFT being minted, if its left blank we will assign one which will be returned in the response.

wallet_address.description: Wallet address to mint token to.

email.description: If absent, the wallet_address will be required.

token_id.description: Token id of the minted token
The token id to transfer, must exist and belong to from_user

from_wallet_address.description: The wallet address owns the token at the contract address

to_wallet_address.description: The recipient wallet address of the token

to_email.description: If absent, the to_wallet_address will be required.

from_email.description: If absent, the from_wallet_address will be required.

email.description: If absent, the wallet_address will be required.

image.description: This is the URL to the image of the item. Can be just about any type of image (including SVG, which will be converted into PNG), and can be IPFS URLs or paths. We recommend using a 350 x 350 image.

animation_url.description:
A URL to a multimedia attachment for the item.The file extensions GLTF, GLB, WEBM, MP4, M4V, OGV, and OGG are supported, along with the audio-only extensions MP3, WAV, and OGA.

Animation_url also supports HTML pages, allowing you to build rich experiences and interactive NFTs using JavaScript canvas WebGL, and more. Scripts and relative paths within the HTML page are now supported. However, access to browser extensions is not supported.

description.description: A human-readable description of the item. Markdown is supported.

attributes.description: These are the attributes for the item, which will show up on the item page on Mintable and other marketplaces.

title.description: Title of this NFT, can be same as name, this is used to list item for sales.

subtitle.description: Short description or subtitle of NFT, can be same as description, this is used to list item for sales.

metadata.description: If absent, the metadata defined in the project will be used.

wallet_address.description: Wallet address to mint token to.

premint_id.description: The premint_id is an optional field. It represents the unique identifier for a premint, which is used to mint a NFT. If the user provides a premint_id, it will be used to identify the specific premint to be used for NFT minting. The premint_id can be obtained from the list premint APIs.

token_id.description: Token id of the minted token

wallet_address.description: Wallet address of the user to mint the token to if you don't pass in a user name.

email.description: Optional Mintable wallet or Mintable's user email for minting the NFT to that wallet.

premint_id.description: The premint_id is an optional field. It represents the unique identifier for a premint, which is used to mint a NFT. If the user provides a premint_id, it will be used to identify the specific premint to be used for NFT minting. The premint_id can be obtained from the list premint APIs.

image.description: This is the URL to the image of the item. Can be just about any type of image (including SVG, which will be converted into PNG), and can be IPFS URLs or paths. We recommend using a 350 x 350 image.

animation_url.description:
A URL to a multimedia attachment for the item.The file extensions GLTF, GLB, WEBM, MP4, M4V, OGV, and OGG are supported, along with the audio-only extensions MP3, WAV, and OGA.

Animation_url also supports HTML pages, allowing you to build rich experiences and interactive NFTs using JavaScript canvas WebGL, and more. Scripts and relative paths within the HTML page are now supported. However, access to browser extensions is not supported.

description.description: A human-readable description of the item. Markdown is supported.

attributes.description: These are the attributes for the item, which will show up on the item page on Mintable and other marketplaces.

title.description: Title of this NFT, can be same as name, this is used to list item for sales.

subtitle.description: Short description or subtitle of NFT, can be same as description, this is used to list item for sales.

metadata.description: Optional metadata to associate with minted token, if you don't have a preminted NFT in the dashboard, you need to pass in your own metadata to use.

token_id.description: Token id of the minted token

email.description: The email address of the user whose wallet to find

username.description: Optional: Username that has a Mintable.com account with a wallet connected to that username.

email.description: The email address of the user whose wallet will be tied to.

username.description: Username that will be tied to using this wallet, it is generated by us randomly and can be changed on Mintable.com

wallet_address.description: The wallet address that was created.

email.description: The username associated with the custodial wallet to be removed.

last_eight_digits_privatekey_hash.description: The SHA256 hash of the last eight digits of the private key associated with the custodial wallet to be removed.

success.description: Indicates whether the removal was successful or not.

email.description: The email address of the user whose wallet is tied to.

request_id.description: The request ID given from calling wallet export.

code.description: When you call the `Request Export` endpoint, we send the owner of the custodial wallet an email to inform them and verify they really intend to claim custody of their wallet. That email contains an OTP code, which has to be provided here.

username.description: Username of the account requesting the export

email.description: Email of the account requesting the export

request_id.description: The `request_id` returned by the `Request Export` endpoint.

premint_id.description: Premint_id can be found by calling premint/list to get all the preminted NFT's IDs and then you can pass it in here to modifiy that preminted NFT data set. If you do not pass in a premint_id, we will create a new preminted NFT data set.

quantity.description: Number of NFTs to be created with this data set. Example, you want to create 100 NFTs that are all the same, or only 1, quantity will determine that count.

image.description: This is the URL to the image of the item. Can be just about any type of image (including SVG, which will be converted into PNG), and can be IPFS URLs or paths. We recommend using a 350 x 350 image.

animation_url.description:
A URL to a multimedia attachment for the item.The file extensions GLTF, GLB, WEBM, MP4, M4V, OGV, and OGG are supported, along with the audio-only extensions MP3, WAV, and OGA.

Animation_url also supports HTML pages, allowing you to build rich experiences and interactive NFTs using JavaScript canvas WebGL, and more. Scripts and relative paths within the HTML page are now supported. However, access to browser extensions is not supported.

subtitle.description: Short description or subtitle of NFT, can be same as description, this is used to list item for sales.

metadata.description: The metadata for the NFT pre-mint data, such as image, url, and additional properties to be on the NFT.

quantity.description: Number of NFTs to be created with this data set. Example, you want to create 100 NFTs that are all the same, or only 1, quantity will determine that count.

description.description: A human-readable description of the item. Markdown is supported.

attributes.description: These are the attributes for the item, which will show up on the item page on Mintable and other marketplaces.

title.description: Title of this NFT, can be same as name, this is used to list item for sales.

subtitle.description: Short description or subtitle of NFT, can be same as description, this is used to list item for sales.

metadata.description: The metadata for the NFT pre-mint data, such as image, url, and additional properties to be on the NFT.

url.description: This is an optional field that specifies the URL of the data source that you want to import. The URL should be a valid and accessible web address that contains the data in a compatible format. For example, you can use a URL that points to a CSV file, a JSON file, or an API endpoint that returns the data as JSON. The url field is optional, which means that you can either provide a URL or an array of input items to import data. If you provide a URL, the service will import data from the specified URL.

premint_id.description: Premint_id can be found by calling premint/list to get all the preminted NFT's IDs and then you can pass it in here to modifiy that preminted NFT data set. If you do not pass in a premint_id, we will create a new preminted NFT data set.

quantity.description: Number of NFTs to be created with this data set. Example, you want to create 100 NFTs that are all the same, or only 1, quantity will determine that count.

image.description: This is the URL to the image of the item. Can be just about any type of image (including SVG, which will be converted into PNG), and can be IPFS URLs or paths. We recommend using a 350 x 350 image.

animation_url.description:
A URL to a multimedia attachment for the item.The file extensions GLTF, GLB, WEBM, MP4, M4V, OGV, and OGG are supported, along with the audio-only extensions MP3, WAV, and OGA.

Animation_url also supports HTML pages, allowing you to build rich experiences and interactive NFTs using JavaScript canvas WebGL, and more. Scripts and relative paths within the HTML page are now supported. However, access to browser extensions is not supported.

description.description: A human-readable description of the item. Markdown is supported.

attributes.description: These are the attributes for the item, which will show up on the item page on Mintable and other marketplaces.

title.description: Title of this NFT, can be same as name, this is used to list item for sales.

subtitle.description: Short description or subtitle of NFT, can be same as description, this is used to list item for sales.

metadata.description: The metadata for the NFT pre-mint data, such as image, url, and additional properties to be on the NFT.

items.description: This is also an optional field that specifies an array of pre-mint user input items. These are objects that contain the information and metadata for each item that you want to mint. The items field is also optional, which means that you can either provide an array of input items or a URL to import data. If you provide an array of input items, each item in the array should have the following properties such as quantity, and metadata.

last_evaluated_key.description: If last_evaluated_key exists, it indicates that all the requested results don't fit in a single page, last_evaluated_key is provided in the response and you can include it in a subsequent request to fetch the next page of results.

name.description: The name of your NFT project that is displayed on the Mintology dashboard. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

description.description: The description of your NFT project.

mint_limit_per_address.description: This field represents the maximum number of NFTs that a single wallet can mint. It sets a limit to prevent any single wallet from minting an excessive number of NFTs. This limit should be less than or equal to the total supply of NFTs if the total supply is set.

contract_type.description: Whether its a shared contract that multiple brands can mint under (no deployment costs), a dedicated contract you control and deploy, or an existing contract you've already deployed and used on another project. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

wallet_type.description: Select Non-custodial if you expect your users to already have a crypto wallet. Or if your users most likely don't have a crypto wallet, then select custodial. If a few users have a wallet, they can use their existing wallet and not need to create a custodial wallet.

base_uri.description: Base URI for metadata, if you want to use your own storage. If you leave this blank, we will handle this for you.

contract_name.description: The contract name that will appear in the blockchain. When creating the Project through Dashboard, this is set from the "name" parameter input. This is required if you select "Dedicated" as contract type. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

symbol.description: The shortened term or ticker symbol unique to your contract (for example "XYZ"). This is required if you select "Dedicated" as contract type. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

royalty.description: Royalty for secondary sales, in % - this uses ERC-2981 for on-chain royalties so that when any NFT is sold on a marketplace that supports on-chain royalties you will get this percentage of the sale. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

total_supply.description: This is an optional field that specifies the total supply of your NFTs in your dedicated smart contract. You can provide the value if you choose dedicated smart contract or existing smart contracts as your contract type, This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.. If you leave this empty, it will set unlimited number of NFTs that can be minted If you enter 100, only 100 NFTs can ever be minted under this contract.

contract_address.description: If you want to reuse one of your existing smart contract (example using the same contract that was created for a different project).

owner_address.description: This field is optional and is used when the contract type is set to "Dedicated". The user can provide their wallet address which will be set as the owner of the deployed smart contract. It's important that this address is not a public address of someone else, as it's like taking ownership of the contract. If left empty, Mintology's address will be set as the owner. Users can later request Mintology to transfer the ownership after the contract deployment.

network.description: This is your network you want to deploy it to on Ethereum, your options are MAINNET = 1, SEPOLIA = 11155111 This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

chain.description: The blockchain you want to use, either Ethereum or IMX. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

name.description: The name of your NFT project that is displayed on the Mintology dashboard. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

description.description: The description of your NFT project.

mint_limit_per_address.description: This field represents the maximum number of NFTs that a single wallet can mint. It sets a limit to prevent any single wallet from minting an excessive number of NFTs. This limit should be less than or equal to the total supply of NFTs if the total supply is set.

base_uri.description: Base URI for metadata, if you want to use your own storage. If you leave this blank, we will handle this for you.

contract_name.description: The contract name that will appear in the blockchain. When creating the Project through Dashboard, this is set from the "name" parameter input. This is required if you select "Dedicated" as contract type. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

symbol.description: The shortened term or ticker symbol unique to your contract (for example "XYZ"). This is required if you select "Dedicated" as contract type. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

royalty.description: Royalty for secondary sales, in % - this uses ERC-2981 for on-chain royalties so that when any NFT is sold on a marketplace that supports on-chain royalties you will get this percentage of the sale. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

total_supply.description: This is an optional field that specifies the total supply of your NFTs in your dedicated smart contract. You can provide the value if you choose dedicated smart contract or existing smart contracts as your contract type, This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.. If you leave this empty, it will set unlimited number of NFTs that can be minted If you enter 100, only 100 NFTs can ever be minted under this contract.

contract_address.description: If you want to reuse one of your existing smart contract (example using the same contract that was created for a different project).

owner_address.description: This field is optional and is used when the contract type is set to "Dedicated". The user can provide their wallet address which will be set as the owner of the deployed smart contract. It's important that this address is not a public address of someone else, as it's like taking ownership of the contract. If left empty, Mintology's address will be set as the owner. Users can later request Mintology to transfer the ownership after the contract deployment.

network.description: This is your network you want to deploy it to on Ethereum, your options are MAINNET = 1, SEPOLIA = 11155111 This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

chain.description: The blockchain you want to use, either Ethereum or IMX. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

post.description:
IMPORTANT: Call from the back-end.

This endpoint is used to check if a user owns a particular token (or any token of a particular collection). You will need to authenticate using your Mintology API Key, and also the Project ID that you set for one of your projects. If you do not specify a contract_address, we will use the contract associated with your project ID. If you do not specify a token_id, we will check if the wallet contain any tokens from the contract.

contract_address.description: The NFT smart contract address to check. This is the address of the NFT contract on the blockchain. If you do not specify a contract_address, we will use the contract associated with your project ID.

token_id.description: NFT token ID to check. This is the token id of the specific NFT token within the contract and it is optional; if absent, any token in the contract will authorize the wallet.

wallet_address.description: Wallet address of the user to authorize the token to if you don't pass in a user name.

email.description: Optional Mintable wallet or Mintable's user email for authorize the NFT to that wallet.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

parameters.name: nextToken
parameters.description: When there are more than 15 tokens returned, pagination occurs and you are returned 'next_token' which you can include in the subsequent request to fetch the next page of results in this parameter.

authorized.description: Whether the wallet address has the NFT and is authorized (the wallet address contains the specified NFT or any NFT from the collection)

next_token.description: If next_token exists, it indicates that all the requested results don't fit in a single page, next_token is provided in the response and you can include it in a subsequent request to fetch the next page of results.

post.description:
IMPORTANT: Call from the back-end.

This endpoint is used to get the list of tokens that a user owns from a particular collection. You will need to authenticate using your Mintology API Key, and also the Project ID that you set for your project. If you do not specify a contract_address, we will use the contract associated with your project.

wallet_address.description: The wallet address of a user to return the information from this wallet.

email.description: Optional Mintable wallet or Mintable's user email for authorize the NFT to that wallet.

contract_address.description: The NFT smart contract address to check. This is the address of the NFT contract on the blockchain. Optional: If you do not specify a contract_address, we will use the contract associated with your project ID.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

parameters.name: exclusiveStartKey
parameters.description: When there are more than 15 tokens returned, pagination occurs and you are returned 'last_evaluated_key' which you can include in the subsequent request to fetch the next page of results in this parameter.

token_ids.description: A list of owned NFT token IDs

last_evaluated_key.description: If last_evaluated_key exists, it indicates that all the requested results don't fit in a single page, last_evaluated_key is provided in the response and you can include it in a subsequent request to fetch the next page of results.

get.description:
Retrieve project information such as name and contract_address.
Alternative : Use Project Retrieve from backend if you need a more in-depth project details.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

used_quantity.description: The quantity of NFTs that have been minted for this project.

contract_address.description: The NFT smart contract address associated with your project ID.

put.description: IMPORTANT: Call from the back-end. Update your NFT metadata that consist of things like: token name, image, animation_url and etc... The URL where you can access the metadata is https://metadata.mintology.app/{projectId}/{tokenId} (for production), or https://metadata.mintology.dev/{projectId}/{tokenId} (for the testing environment).

image.description: This is the URL to the image of the item. Can be just about any type of image (including SVG, which will be converted into PNG), and can be IPFS URLs or paths. We recommend using a 350 x 350 image.

animation_url.description:
A URL to a multimedia attachment for the item.The file extensions GLTF, GLB, WEBM, MP4, M4V, OGV, and OGG are supported, along with the audio-only extensions MP3, WAV, and OGA.

Animation_url also supports HTML pages, allowing you to build rich experiences and interactive NFTs using JavaScript canvas WebGL, and more. Scripts and relative paths within the HTML page are now supported. However, access to browser extensions is not supported.

description.description: A human-readable description of the item. Markdown is supported.

attributes.description: These are the attributes for the item, which will show up on the item page on Mintable and other marketplaces.

title.description: Title of this NFT, can be same as name, this is used to list item for sales.

subtitle.description: Short description or subtitle of NFT, can be same as description, this is used to list item for sales.

metadata.description: Required: The new metadata (will replace the existing metadata)

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

parameters.name: tokenId
parameters.description: tokenId

post.description: Generating an ImmutableX L2 user account for an Ethereum L1 account

username.description: Optional username that will be tied to this private key/wallet

email.description: Email address that will be tied to this private key/wallet

force_overwrite_linked_wallet.description: Overwrite the currently linked wallet address forcefully

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

wallet_address.description: The wallet address of a user to return the information from this wallet.

post.description: Minting an NFT refers to the process of creating a unique digital asset on a IMX blockchain, typically using the Ethereum network.

image.description: This is the URL to the image of the item. Can be just about any type of image (including SVG, which will be converted into PNG), and can be IPFS URLs or paths. We recommend using a 350 x 350 image.

animation_url.description:
A URL to a multimedia attachment for the item.The file extensions GLTF, GLB, WEBM, MP4, M4V, OGV, and OGG are supported, along with the audio-only extensions MP3, WAV, and OGA.

Animation_url also supports HTML pages, allowing you to build rich experiences and interactive NFTs using JavaScript canvas WebGL, and more. Scripts and relative paths within the HTML page are now supported. However, access to browser extensions is not supported.

description.description: A human-readable description of the item. Markdown is supported.

attributes.description: These are the attributes for the item, which will show up on the item page on Mintable and other marketplaces.

title.description: Title of this NFT, can be same as name, this is used to list item for sales.

subtitle.description: Short description or subtitle of NFT, can be same as description, this is used to list item for sales.

metadata.description: Metadata for the NFT being minted. If absent, the metadata defined in the project will be used.

token_id.description: A unique token id for the NFT being minted, if its left blank we will assign one which will be returned in the response.

wallet_address.description: Wallet address to mint token to.

email.description: If absent, the wallet_address will be required.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

token_id.description: Token id of the minted token

post.description: Transferring an NFT, or a non-fungible token, refers to the process of sending ownership of the digital asset from one address on the IMX blockchain to another.

token_id.description: The token id to transfer, must exist and belong to from_user

from_wallet_address.description: The wallet address owns the token at the contract address

to_wallet_address.description: The recipient wallet address of the token

to_email.description: If absent, the to_wallet_address will be required.

from_email.description: If absent, the from_wallet_address will be required.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

post.description: This API endpoint is designed for minting NFTs straight into a user's wallet. Ideal for selling NFTs, targeted airdrops, or minting collectibles. Supports both custom Mintable Wallets and standard crypto wallets. Note: If you don't pass in a metadata object - it will create a random NFT using your pre-mint data you've set up on the self serve dashboard. But if you pass in a metadata object, it will mint a new NFT with the new metadata object you passed in. Note: Keeping 'mint' and 'claim' endpoints separate simplifies analytics, making it easier to track each call's specific purpose.

email.description: If absent, the wallet_address will be required.

image.description: This is the URL to the image of the item. Can be just about any type of image (including SVG, which will be converted into PNG), and can be IPFS URLs or paths. We recommend using a 350 x 350 image.

animation_url.description:
A URL to a multimedia attachment for the item.The file extensions GLTF, GLB, WEBM, MP4, M4V, OGV, and OGG are supported, along with the audio-only extensions MP3, WAV, and OGA.

Animation_url also supports HTML pages, allowing you to build rich experiences and interactive NFTs using JavaScript canvas WebGL, and more. Scripts and relative paths within the HTML page are now supported. However, access to browser extensions is not supported.

description.description: A human-readable description of the item. Markdown is supported.

attributes.description: These are the attributes for the item, which will show up on the item page on Mintable and other marketplaces.

title.description: Title of this NFT, can be same as name, this is used to list item for sales.

subtitle.description: Short description or subtitle of NFT, can be same as description, this is used to list item for sales.

metadata.description: If absent, the metadata defined in the project will be used.

wallet_address.description: Wallet address to mint token to.

premint_id.description: The premint_id is an optional field. It represents the unique identifier for a premint, which is used to mint a NFT. If the user provides a premint_id, it will be used to identify the specific premint to be used for NFT minting. The premint_id can be obtained from the list premint APIs.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

token_id.description: Token id of the minted token

post.description: This endpoint will mint a free NFT to your user's wallet (which can be a Mintable Wallet, or their existing crypto wallet). This is the endpoint you should use for discount coupons, proof of attendance, and in general NFTs which you do not intend to sell. Note: Separating the mint and claim endpoints will allow you to clearly identify the purpose of each call in your analytics.

wallet_address.description: Wallet address of the user to mint the token to if you don't pass in a user name.

email.description: Optional Mintable wallet or Mintable's user email for minting the NFT to that wallet.

premint_id.description: The premint_id is an optional field. It represents the unique identifier for a premint, which is used to mint a NFT. If the user provides a premint_id, it will be used to identify the specific premint to be used for NFT minting. The premint_id can be obtained from the list premint APIs.

image.description: This is the URL to the image of the item. Can be just about any type of image (including SVG, which will be converted into PNG), and can be IPFS URLs or paths. We recommend using a 350 x 350 image.

animation_url.description:
A URL to a multimedia attachment for the item.The file extensions GLTF, GLB, WEBM, MP4, M4V, OGV, and OGG are supported, along with the audio-only extensions MP3, WAV, and OGA.

Animation_url also supports HTML pages, allowing you to build rich experiences and interactive NFTs using JavaScript canvas WebGL, and more. Scripts and relative paths within the HTML page are now supported. However, access to browser extensions is not supported.

description.description: A human-readable description of the item. Markdown is supported.

attributes.description: These are the attributes for the item, which will show up on the item page on Mintable and other marketplaces.

title.description: Title of this NFT, can be same as name, this is used to list item for sales.

subtitle.description: Short description or subtitle of NFT, can be same as description, this is used to list item for sales.

metadata.description: Optional metadata to associate with minted token, if you don't have a preminted NFT in the dashboard, you need to pass in your own metadata to use.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

token_id.description: Token id of the minted token

post.description:
IMPORTANT: Call from the back-end.

Create a new Mintable Wallet. This also creates a Mintable account, so users have the ability to claim custody of their private keys. Please note that a username can be provided: if you do not provide a username, a random one will be generated and the user will be able to modify it from the Mintable website. This is a display name used on the site to reference the user, since the email address is confidential.

This endpoint should always be called from your backend to prevent any potential spamming or exposing your private API key.

email.description: The email address of the user whose wallet to find

username.description: Optional: Username that has a Mintable.com account with a wallet connected to that username.

email.description: The email address of the user whose wallet will be tied to.

username.description: Username that will be tied to using this wallet, it is generated by us randomly and can be changed on Mintable.com

wallet_address.description: The wallet address that was created.

delete.description:
IMPORTANT: Call from the back-end.

Once a user has taken custody of their Mintable Wallet, this permanently removes the private key from our systems. To ensure the user has indeed received and stored their private key, we require you to send us a hash of the last 8 characters of the key itself: once we have checked it against the actual key and, if the match is successful, we delete the key. The hash function used here is SHA-256 (please see this example).

This endpoint should always be called from your backend to prevent any potential spamming or exposing your private API key.

email.description: The username associated with the custodial wallet to be removed.

last_eight_digits_privatekey_hash.description: The SHA256 hash of the last eight digits of the private key associated with the custodial wallet to be removed.

requestBody.description: Interface for a request to remove a custodial wallet.

parameters.name: walletAddress
parameters.description: The address of the custodial wallet that is being removed.

200.description: Interface for the response of removing a custodial wallet.

success.description: Indicates whether the removal was successful or not.

post.description:
IMPORTANT: Call from the back-end.

When a user wants to take custody of their Mintable Wallet, you can call this endpoint to initiate the process. When you call the endpoint, we will send an email to the user, with an OTP which will have to be provided to access the private key of the wallet. This flow ensures that the request was indeed initiated by the user, since we will be sending this email from our systems. In order to access the private key, both the OTP sent to the user, and the request ID returned by this endpoint will have to be provided.

This endpoint should always be called from your backend to prevent any potential spamming or exposing your private API key.

email.description: The email address of the user whose wallet is tied to.

parameters.name: walletAddress
parameters.description: The address of the custodial wallet that is being removed.

request_id.description: The request ID given from calling wallet export.

post.description:
IMPORTANT: Call from the back-end.

Export the Mintable wallet private key. This endpoint requires the request_id (which you got when calling 'Request to Export Mintable Wallet', and the OTP which was sent to the user by that endpoint (called code here).

This endpoint should always be called from your backend to prevent any potential spamming or exposing your private API key.

code.description: When you call the `Request Export` endpoint, we send the owner of the custodial wallet an email to inform them and verify they really intend to claim custody of their wallet. That email contains an OTP code, which has to be provided here.

username.description: Username of the account requesting the export

email.description: Email of the account requesting the export

request_id.description: The `request_id` returned by the `Request Export` endpoint.

parameters.name: walletAddress
parameters.description: The address of the custodial wallet that is being removed.

get.description: Returns a list of premint items. The premints are returned sorted by updated date, with the most recent premints before.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

200.description: Returns a list of premint objects with attributes like id, name, image_url etc

premint_id.description: Premint_id can be found by calling premint/list to get all the preminted NFT's IDs and then you can pass it in here to modifiy that preminted NFT data set. If you do not pass in a premint_id, we will create a new preminted NFT data set.

quantity.description: Number of NFTs to be created with this data set. Example, you want to create 100 NFTs that are all the same, or only 1, quantity will determine that count.

image.description: This is the URL to the image of the item. Can be just about any type of image (including SVG, which will be converted into PNG), and can be IPFS URLs or paths. We recommend using a 350 x 350 image.

animation_url.description:
A URL to a multimedia attachment for the item.The file extensions GLTF, GLB, WEBM, MP4, M4V, OGV, and OGG are supported, along with the audio-only extensions MP3, WAV, and OGA.

Animation_url also supports HTML pages, allowing you to build rich experiences and interactive NFTs using JavaScript canvas WebGL, and more. Scripts and relative paths within the HTML page are now supported. However, access to browser extensions is not supported.

description.description: A human-readable description of the item. Markdown is supported.

attributes.description: These are the attributes for the item, which will show up on the item page on Mintable and other marketplaces.

title.description: Title of this NFT, can be same as name, this is used to list item for sales.

subtitle.description: Short description or subtitle of NFT, can be same as description, this is used to list item for sales.

metadata.description: The metadata for the NFT pre-mint data, such as image, url, and additional properties to be on the NFT.

last_evaluated_key.description: If last_evaluated_key exists, it indicates that all the requested results don't fit in a single page, last_evaluated_key is provided in the response and you can include it in a subsequent request to fetch the next page of results.

post.description: Create token details like name, image, animation_url and etc...

quantity.description: Number of NFTs to be created with this data set. Example, you want to create 100 NFTs that are all the same, or only 1, quantity will determine that count.

image.description: This is the URL to the image of the item. Can be just about any type of image (including SVG, which will be converted into PNG), and can be IPFS URLs or paths. We recommend using a 350 x 350 image.

animation_url.description:
A URL to a multimedia attachment for the item.The file extensions GLTF, GLB, WEBM, MP4, M4V, OGV, and OGG are supported, along with the audio-only extensions MP3, WAV, and OGA.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

parameters.name: premintId
parameters.description: premintId

post.description: Import token details like name, image, animation_url and etc...

url.description: This is an optional field that specifies the URL of the data source that you want to import. The URL should be a valid and accessible web address that contains the data in a compatible format. For example, you can use a URL that points to a CSV file, a JSON file, or an API endpoint that returns the data as JSON. The url field is optional, which means that you can either provide a URL or an array of input items to import data. If you provide a URL, the service will import data from the specified URL.

premint_id.description: Premint_id can be found by calling premint/list to get all the preminted NFT's IDs and then you can pass it in here to modifiy that preminted NFT data set. If you do not pass in a premint_id, we will create a new preminted NFT data set.

quantity.description: Number of NFTs to be created with this data set. Example, you want to create 100 NFTs that are all the same, or only 1, quantity will determine that count.

image.description: This is the URL to the image of the item. Can be just about any type of image (including SVG, which will be converted into PNG), and can be IPFS URLs or paths. We recommend using a 350 x 350 image.

animation_url.description:
A URL to a multimedia attachment for the item.The file extensions GLTF, GLB, WEBM, MP4, M4V, OGV, and OGG are supported, along with the audio-only extensions MP3, WAV, and OGA.

Animation_url also supports HTML pages, allowing you to build rich experiences and interactive NFTs using JavaScript canvas WebGL, and more. Scripts and relative paths within the HTML page are now supported. However, access to browser extensions is not supported.

description.description: A human-readable description of the item. Markdown is supported.

attributes.description: These are the attributes for the item, which will show up on the item page on Mintable and other marketplaces.

title.description: Title of this NFT, can be same as name, this is used to list item for sales.

subtitle.description: Short description or subtitle of NFT, can be same as description, this is used to list item for sales.

metadata.description: The metadata for the NFT pre-mint data, such as image, url, and additional properties to be on the NFT.

items.description: This is also an optional field that specifies an array of pre-mint user input items. These are objects that contain the information and metadata for each item that you want to mint. The items field is also optional, which means that you can either provide an array of input items or a URL to import data. If you provide an array of input items, each item in the array should have the following properties such as quantity, and metadata.

requestBody.description: You can use either the url or the items field to provide the data to import to pre-mints, but not both. If you use both, the service will use items. If you use neither, the service will also give an error. You need to use at least one of them to import your pre-mints successfully.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

get.description:
IMPORTANT: Call from the back-end.

Requires: API KEY in the header. Returns a list of all projects you have created.

last_evaluated_key.description: If last_evaluated_key exists, it indicates that all the requested results don't fit in a single page, last_evaluated_key is provided in the response and you can include it in a subsequent request to fetch the next page of results.

post.description:
IMPORTANT: Call from the back-end.

Requires: API KEY in the header. Creates a new project under your account with the specified details.

name.description: The name of your NFT project that is displayed on the Mintology dashboard. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

description.description: The description of your NFT project.

mint_limit_per_address.description: This field represents the maximum number of NFTs that a single wallet can mint. It sets a limit to prevent any single wallet from minting an excessive number of NFTs. This limit should be less than or equal to the total supply of NFTs if the total supply is set.

contract_type.description: Whether its a shared contract that multiple brands can mint under (no deployment costs), a dedicated contract you control and deploy, or an existing contract you've already deployed and used on another project. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

wallet_type.description: Select Non-custodial if you expect your users to already have a crypto wallet. Or if your users most likely don't have a crypto wallet, then select custodial. If a few users have a wallet, they can use their existing wallet and not need to create a custodial wallet.

base_uri.description: Base URI for metadata, if you want to use your own storage. If you leave this blank, we will handle this for you.

contract_name.description: The contract name that will appear in the blockchain. When creating the Project through Dashboard, this is set from the "name" parameter input. This is required if you select "Dedicated" as contract type. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

symbol.description: The shortened term or ticker symbol unique to your contract (for example "XYZ"). This is required if you select "Dedicated" as contract type. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

royalty.description: Royalty for secondary sales, in % - this uses ERC-2981 for on-chain royalties so that when any NFT is sold on a marketplace that supports on-chain royalties you will get this percentage of the sale. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

total_supply.description: This is an optional field that specifies the total supply of your NFTs in your dedicated smart contract. You can provide the value if you choose dedicated smart contract or existing smart contracts as your contract type, This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.. If you leave this empty, it will set unlimited number of NFTs that can be minted If you enter 100, only 100 NFTs can ever be minted under this contract.

contract_address.description: If you want to reuse one of your existing smart contract (example using the same contract that was created for a different project).

owner_address.description: This field is optional and is used when the contract type is set to "Dedicated". The user can provide their wallet address which will be set as the owner of the deployed smart contract. It's important that this address is not a public address of someone else, as it's like taking ownership of the contract. If left empty, Mintology's address will be set as the owner. Users can later request Mintology to transfer the ownership after the contract deployment.

network.description: This is your network you want to deploy it to on Ethereum, your options are MAINNET = 1, SEPOLIA = 11155111 This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

chain.description: The blockchain you want to use, either Ethereum or IMX. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

name.description: The name of your NFT project that is displayed on the Mintology dashboard. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

description.description: The description of your NFT project.

mint_limit_per_address.description: This field represents the maximum number of NFTs that a single wallet can mint. It sets a limit to prevent any single wallet from minting an excessive number of NFTs. This limit should be less than or equal to the total supply of NFTs if the total supply is set.

contract_type.description: Whether its a shared contract that multiple brands can mint under (no deployment costs), a dedicated contract you control and deploy, or an existing contract you've already deployed and used on another project. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

wallet_type.description: Select Non-custodial if you expect your users to already have a crypto wallet. Or if your users most likely don't have a crypto wallet, then select custodial. If a few users have a wallet, they can use their existing wallet and not need to create a custodial wallet.

royalty.description: Royalty for secondary sales, in % - this uses ERC-2981 for on-chain royalties so that when any NFT is sold on a marketplace that supports on-chain royalties you will get this percentage of the sale. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

total_supply.description: This is an optional field that specifies the total supply of your NFTs in your dedicated smart contract. You can provide the value if you choose dedicated smart contract or existing smart contracts as your contract type, This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.. If you leave this empty, it will set unlimited number of NFTs that can be minted If you enter 100, only 100 NFTs can ever be minted under this contract.

contract_address.description: If you want to reuse one of your existing smart contract (example using the same contract that was created for a different project).

owner_address.description: This field is optional and is used when the contract type is set to "Dedicated". The user can provide their wallet address which will be set as the owner of the deployed smart contract. It's important that this address is not a public address of someone else, as it's like taking ownership of the contract. If left empty, Mintology's address will be set as the owner. Users can later request Mintology to transfer the ownership after the contract deployment.

network.description: This is your network you want to deploy it to on Ethereum, your options are MAINNET = 1, SEPOLIA = 11155111 This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

chain.description: The blockchain you want to use, either Ethereum or IMX. This cannot be changed once the contract is deployed.

get.description:
IMPORTANT: Call from the back-end.

Requires: API KEY in the header. This will return all of the projects details of the project that is specified by its project ID.
Alternative : Use Project Info you need a just the contract_address and the name, Project Info can be called from front-end too

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

put.description:
IMPORTANT: Call from the back-end.

Requires: API KEY in the header. Updates the project with the specified ID with the specified details. Please check `/Projects/Create` for a description of the parameters.

description.description: The description of your NFT project.

delete.description: Delete a project from the platform. But once deployed the smart contract will exist on the blockchain and you will be able to manage it without Mintology. This is a permanent action and cannot be undone.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

put.description: IMPORTANT: This operation should be initiated from the back-end. Requires: API KEY in the header. This will update the project mint configuration using the provided ID and details. Additionally, this operation allows enabling or disabling of the mint. However, this can only be toggled after the project has been successfully deployed.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

put.description: IMPORTANT: This operation should be initiated from the back-end. Requires: API KEY in the header. This will update the project claim configuration using the provided ID and details. Additionally, this operation allows enabling or disabling of the claim. However, this can only be toggled after the project has been successfully deployed.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app

post.description:
IMPORTANT: Call from the back-end.

Requires: API KEY in the header.

Deploy the project with the specified ID with the specified details. A project must be deployed before tokens can be minted.

IMPORTANT: If you are using Generative NFTs on the dashboard, you need to make the NFTs before deploying.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: Project Id - found on your dashboard on dashboard.mintology.app
